Fields.DialogueText: She can see anything that goes on in the ship, you know. Because she is the ship.
Surely she isn't paying attention all the time, though?
You don't want to count on that. Especially if you're thinking of that lady in the radio room you've been flirting with at dinner.
I, er...
Trust me, the Countess is stricter than a school nun when it comes to fraternizing.
Gentlemen, I see a lot of chatter and not a lot of work being done.
Erk. Sorry, Captain. My friend here just needed some setting straight.
...The Countess?
Er, yeah. Conte di Cavour, except she's a lady, so...
I see.

Fields.MenuText: It's a... respectful term, I suppose.
I wonder if that's something you would call her to her face.
Is that how you think of her?

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, we wouldn't want to be disrespectful to the lady of the ship.
No, Captain. To her face she is always "ma'am."
It's just what the crew calls her. Privately, you see.
She's not a lady to cross, though you surely know that.
*ALARM*
Erk! Duty calls!
@BATTLE
I wouldn't expect to have to explain it. Besides maintaining the moral character of the crew, relationships between men and women on a ship come with unwanted consequences.
I can understand that. But people seem uncomfortable knowing you could be watching them at any minute.
I fail to see a problem.
You like having them be afraid of you?
When it suits.
Capitano, you have heard of the philosophies of Machiavelli, yes? Particularly, The Prince?
You mean the stuff about "better to be feared than loved."
There is more, but that is the part I'm referring to. Only you have given the popular mis-quotation.
"It is far safer to be feared than loved if you cannot be both." You see, most people are driven by their emotions.
Though I prefer not to be cruel, as Machiavelli recommends for soldiers, a little fear breeds respect and reinforces discipline.

Fields.MenuText: I would rather be respected for being a good captain.
It could also breed resentment.
I guess there's such a thing as a little healthy fear...

Fields.DialogueText: That's a worthy goal. But in tough times, admiration gives way to self-preservation.
That is why you must apply restraint. If they hate you, they are likely to rebel.
Indeed. If men did not fear breaking the law, they would not be deterred from it.
I must stop this conversation here. There's commotion in the radio room...a distress call.
Morganas?
I would bet on it.
@BATTLE
These waters are teeming with Morgana raiding groups.
Capitano, Signora, a word?
Of course.
To put it short and bluntly, we've been running shorthanded and the crew is wearing out. We need fresh bodies.
I'm aware. I had hoped we'd make it to our next port sooner. What do you recommend?
In the short term, we can juggle the shift schedules. Everyone can get more rest, but they'll have to work harder to make up the gap.
But in port, we really need to send the Field Recruitment officers out and take all we can. I know you're usually more selective, but...
I follow you. Moreover, regretfully, I agree with you.
Regretfully?
I see the necessity of Nicola's proposal, but taking on a large influx of recruits will make things harder before they get easier.
And they won't be Italian. It will be even harder for them to integrate with the existing crew.

Fields.MenuText: It will be a challenge, but we'll cope.
I look forward to it. Fresh blood will be welcome around here.
It sounds like it could be a disaster.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed. We can't always expect ideal circumstances.
It will shake things up, that's for sure.
There may be a few of those. But we'll cope.
If anyone needs me, I'll be brushing up on my language studies.
You're moody because you'll have to put off your proposal for the BWC, aren't you?
I won't have it said I'm lax in my duties. The ship must come first.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The gunnery crew on B turret is in chaos! Cavour, you speak some Greek, yes?
Mostly the ancient sort. I will try to sort it out.
This drill is turning out to be a disaster.
Be glad it's a drill. We still have–
Attention, everyone. This is Conte di Cavour. Morgana ships have suddenly appeared to the south of us. This is no longer a drill. Battle stations, immediately!
Cazzo!
@BATTLE
No one else is watching? Good. Excuse me while I collapse into this chair.
That bad?
We survived. That's the only good thing to be said.
By the grace of God, we narrowly avoided exploding our own munitions.
A man was severely burned when one of the boilers went overpressure and vented. A communication error resulted in the valves being set wrong.
I get the idea. I can read the rest when the damage reports come in.

Fields.MenuText: We should have had more time in port to train the recruits.
We just have to be patient. Problems are to be expected.
I knew this would be a disaster.

Fields.DialogueText: We were not afforded that luxury. And so we must push harder.
Problems that risk lives and limbs? We are going to need to try harder than that.
It was. We'll just have to push harder. The Fleet needs us in top form.
Take a break, Capitano. Tired as I am, you're swaying on your feet. My body is made of sterner stuff.
Thanks... I guess.
@BATTLE
This is too much. They expect us to perform in these conditions with an untrained crew?
It could be much worse.
Tell that to that chief surgeon.
Well, the Admiralty has noticed.
(She doesn't already know? Wow, she's really off her game.)
Oh, really? Are they just scolding us or are they offering actual help?
They want to put us under the command of an Admiral...one Ottavianno Zima.
Zima!
Hmm. Zima.
You two know him?
By reputation. Very high in the Regia Marina since the 20s. He is... known to be a hard man. I'm surprised he's working with the INPF.
Signora, haven't you served under him?
I have.

Fields.MenuText: What's he like?
What do you think of him?
Why do you think they're sending him?

Fields.DialogueText: A disciplinarian. He will know a thing or two about whipping the crew into shape.
His reputation precedes him. They must think he'll whip the crew into shape.
Obviously, to whip the crew into shape. He has a reputation...and a lot of influence.
I should warn you both, do not give Zima a reason to find fault with us. His opinion carries a great deal of weight.
With the Fleet? Or the Regia Marina?
Both. You, Nicola, should keep a leash on your opinions. You are a capable officer and I would have no one else. However, we both know why you transferred to an INPF ship.
... Hmmph. Aye, Signora.
Everybody brace yourselves. They'll be in range any minute now.
There is the Admiral's transport to the south...
And there is a Morgana pack to the east.
Damn. Have the radio room contact the Admiral, please? Let's try dealing with this and not look like fools.
@BATTLE
Admiral on the deck!
Ah, Cavour. It is astounding to finally meet you properly, as it were. Do you remember me?
I do.
It's been... about twenty years since Corfu, yes? And you and your sister have risen as the pride of the Italian fleet. How is Giulio Cesare?
Formidable as ever. And I believe she's trained just about herself not to shout at the crew in Latin. I'm sure she'd love to see if you if the opportunity ever presented itself.
It would be a very great pleasure.
(Well, he seems friendly enough.)
And you are the Capitano. Hmmph.
I don't see why Panza shouldn't have continued on as your capitano, Cavour. There was certainly nothing wrong with his loyalty.

Fields.MenuText: I may be an outsider, Admiral, but I am committed to the INPF.
I may be an outsider, Admiral, but Cavour and I work well together.
I assure you that we both are committed to Italy's interests.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. But this is foremost an Italian ship.
I'd think Panza would have worked well too. But the Belles have their ways and they seem to function... adequately.
Are you? We shall see.
Admiral, I will show you to your quarters if you are ready. There is much to be done.
Yes, of course. Very much, from what I've heard...
Is the whole crew assembled?
Yes, Admiral.
Very good.
Sailors! At attention!
I know you have been struggling. It is a long fight and a hard one. We are besieged by an enemy unlike what the world has known before.
Well, put all of that aside! Do not think about the hardship, the danger! You are here for a cause! You are sailors on one of the greatest ships in the world!
You must stand undivided, working and acting as one! You must embrace the struggle as your life's purpose!
If you live and fight, you live as a hero. If you die in the fire of battle, you die a hero. I see more than sailors here... I see heroes in the making!
If you would embrace that destiny, let me hear you swear it! Will you be heroes?
Aye!
Louder!
AYE!
Admiral. Morganas are approaching.
Then let's show them what Italy's best can do.
Heh. Aye!
That was quite the rally.
Indeed. I confess, my skills are more in the line of quiet persuasion.

Fields.MenuText: I've got to say, it motivated me.
All that about dying a hero though... I like living a lot better.
He reminds me of Mussolini. I'm not sure I like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. Brace yourself for the fight to come.
That is an urge that must be overcome. The cause is more important than any one person.
Can you deny its efficacy, though?
Anyway. To business.
@BATTLE
Cavour, the communication between crew members is a mess. Why isn't everyone speaking Italian?
I have encouraged those who wish to learn it, especially the officers and would-be officers.
In the immediate situation, however, it has been faster to drill basic commands and then step in to translate as needed.
In addition, many soldiers are Italian, from towns like Napoli or Sardine. They understand Italian, but prefer to speak their own languages amongst themselves.
Well, no more of that. We will set up language classes. They shall be mandatory for all. The native speakers must help the non-native ones.
Who will organize it? We hardly have a bounty of free time.
I will. Though I will need to delegate heavily to junior officers.
After a grace period of a few weeks, speaking anything but Italian on duty will be grounds for punishment detail. After a while we may consider enforcing it off-duty too.
Admiral? I don't see a need to enforce it off-duty. I sometimes enjoy practicing my foreign languages with the other sailors.
Oh, is Italian not good enough?
I... There is nothing wrong with it. But you know my interest in politics and it is useful to bridge language barriers.
Fair. But beware you aren't catching the Mediterranean inferiority complex. It is an insidious disease.
Admiral.
It's awfully hard to get a word in edgewise with him.
You have thoughts on it?

Fields.MenuText: I get his reasoning, to a point.
I agree with him. With so many foreign recruits, it's a serious problem.
It seems overly harsh. Are we really doing that badly?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye. Communication on a battleship can have life and death impact. But respect begets loyalty.
I don't completely. There are advantages, but it might demoralize the crew.
Communication on a battleship is a life and death issue. But I will weigh the effects of the policy.
... Inferiority complex?
Il Duce's rhetoric. Italy has struggled in the past to maintain a united front. It was only a couple of generations ago that we became a united nation.
Thanks partly to your namesake.
Correct. Before that, our lands were a plaything for the powers of Europe to fight over. Even after, we were cheated out of gains in the last war.
There is racial theory and ideas about Italian's darker skin tones in it, though I find that a stretch when our political history is sufficient reason.
So Zima is a Fascist.
Non-Facists do not rise so high in the Regia Marina, Capitano. If that is a problem for you, I caution you to keep it to yourself. This is still the Neutrality Fleet and we must be professional.
@BATTLE
Where's that pump? Get that pump over here!
I can't find the unload!
The what?
The unload! Where is the unload!
What the hell is an unload!?
Time!
*GROAN*
Arrrgh!
It's not the "unload," scaricare, you dolt. It's "the outlet," l'uscita!
Yes, Admiral.
There is no time to run the drill again today. Tonight you will all clean the toilets.
What? Punishment detail?
It damn well is and I don't want to hear one complaint about it. Maybe it will teach you lot something about plumbing before you have to learn in the middle of an engine room flood!
... Admiral.
Admiral...

Fields.MenuText: They only–
I don't think that–
I know these drills are important, but–

Fields.DialogueText: No questions from you, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Oh, wonderful. Just what we don't need.
(I take back anything I thought about him being friendly.)
@BATTLE
You look wrecked. Drink?
Please.
Capitano, may I speak freely?
Go ahead.
I knew, taking on so many new crew, that the transition would be hard. I'm convinced Zima is making it worse.
All these drills, classes, it would be one thing if we were in port at rest. On top of constant battles? It is too much.
And Zima is handing out punishment detail with a heavy hand. The sailors need to be able to rest and shipboard morale is at risk.
I hear you, Nicola. But Zima will barely acknowledge I exist, much less my command.
That is unfortunate. But we must do something.

Fields.MenuText: We could write a protest to the General Staff?
We could talk to Cavour.
We may have to confront him forcefully.

Fields.DialogueText: It would be a start. But it would take time, and they sent him to us in the first place.
I am not sure whether the Countess would take our side or not. Still, I'd rather face her than him.
A last resort, I think. You might be protected as Cavour's capitano, but anyone below you would be at risk.
Hm. A written complaint might be the easiest first step. At least establish a documentation trail.
I will write it if you will sign it. I know my way around naval command procedures. I have connections that might help it get seen.
Deal. I will try to talk to Cavour about this. She has to at least hear me out.
@BATTLE
Cavour, what is that commotion on the bow deck?
I will check.
... I can't get used to her just disappearing like that.
A ensign caught a group of Greeks speaking Greek to each other mid-fight. It was reported to Zima.
Their punishment is to stand exposed at attention on the bow deck for the next two hours.
"Exposed" meaning...
In their underclothes.
... I have several problems with this. One, this is very unorthodox and I'm not sure it's humane.
Two, none of this has been run by me! Am I not in this chain of command?
I confess I am less than pleased with the way Zima is treating you, Capitano. But strictly speaking, he is within his rights as admiral.

Fields.MenuText: So he's within his rights to run this crew ragged too?
Was the ensign within his rights to go over my head?
So you think he's right to single out the foreign crew?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Legally, yes. But I can try to talk him into easing up the schedules.
... Fair point. Zima has attracted some zealots, but I can remind them about the chain of command.
I agree with the intent of the language policy. I am not sure I would execute it the same way.
Still, the unity of the ship's crew is important. Remember that.
@BATTLE
I came down for a nightcap. What on earth is all that yelling?
A fight broke out in the crew mess. You had better come.
Does Zima know?
No. He's supposed to be asleep, and for God's sake I hope no one wakes him.
All he did was show your lot your place!
I'm telling you, if they hadn't dropped the Italian, they wouldn't have been able to act in time! Stuff got rattled and there were loose munitions rolling about!
But no, Zima's little toady had to rat them out, even though they probably saved the ship from an explosion!
Both of you, stand down this instant!
Oh look, the Countess is talking. Everybody bow down! You're as much his toady as that ensign!
Sailor, you are out of line!
Says the bitch that shelled Corfu!
Capitano. Deal with this.
And what is the Captain going to do about any of this?

Fields.MenuText: I hear your grievances. If everyone calms down and keeps their mouth shut, I will forget any of this happened.
Those who were fighting get the brig for a week, per regulation. I will try to ensure it remains at that.
You are out of line, sailor. You may have some fair complaints, but that is no excuse to speak to our Belle like that. We will talk about this.

Fields.DialogueText: ... harumph.
... harumph. Good luck with that.
... harumph. Fine. But we need to be heard too.
*ALARM*
I trust you two won't kill each other in my abscence?
@BATTLE
So is this what you think of me, you little turncoat?
You haven't even told me what I'm accused of!
Goddamnit! Gentlemen, this is still my bridge and this is not the time!
Capitano, this is Cavour. Morganas confirmed, range in two minutes.
@BATTLE
All right, what the hell is going on? Admiral, obviously you don't like me and I don't think I can change your mind.
But if you're going to scream accusations at my executive officer and one of my best men, you're going to damn well tell me why!
My complaint is this!
The letter... you searched my quarters!?
Nicola has been resistant to enforcing the new policies. He had not made his defiance open, but I was getting suspicious.
We cannot afford any wavering on this! The Admiralty sent me here to get this ship in order and I expect full compliance!
If Nicola is not on board with the program, I don't see how he can continue serving as executive officer.

Fields.MenuText: Zima, how dare you threaten–
Zima, I know about–
Zima, this isn't what you–

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano... no. This is between us.
Capitano... no. This is on me.
Capitano... no. He understands perfectly well.
Admiral, I stand by every word in that letter. I will not recant any of it. Your "program" will prove detrimental to the welfare and morale of this ship.
Then you leave me with no choice...
Damnit, this is madness. Cavour, say something sensible!
Admiral, in light of Nicola's sterling service record, I recommend that you deal with him leniently. The Fleet can ill afford to lose good officers.
Hmmph. Nicola, I relieve you of duty and confine you to quarters until further notice. Don't expect to serve on this ship again anytime soon!
(Damn it, damn it, damn it! Cavour, what the hell?)
*ALARM*
Nicola, I'm so sorry. You didn't have to–
Capitano... I know. I appreciate that you stood up for me.
But if Zima knew we were in on the letter together, we would both be out of commission now. Then no one would be left to stand up to him.
I've got reason to dislike Zima. People like him are why I jumped to the INPF at the first chance.
So I will take the fall. But promise me you will keep fighting this.
Nicola... thank you. I promise. And I think my first step will be to have some words with Cavour...
Later. Morganas might still be hanging around. There will be nothing left to fight for if we get blown out of the water.
@BATTLE
(Ok. Door locked, check. General orders not to disturb me, check.)
Cavour, come here and talk to me right now. That is an order.
Was that necessary, Capitano?
Yes. I want no weasel words, no evasions.
Cavour, what the hell is wrong with you? You're smart enough to trust Nicola when it comes to the welfare of the ship. Yet you practically threw him under the bus!
Technically, he threw himself on his sword to save you.
I'm not blind, Capitano. I realize Zima is being extraordinarily aggressive with his authority and I realize it is causing friction. I am being careful.
He's just as much of an ass as Felix Mercier, maybe more. You were not so hesitant with him.
Mercier is an incompetent lout with little real power. Zima is an admiral with a distinguished service record and rank authority.
The former Captain Panza had authority and a distinguished record too.
He was most distinguished at throwing around his family name and kissing up to superiors.
But you keep making excuses for Zima! Why?

Fields.MenuText: Because you agree with him?
Because you're afraid of him?
Because you don't respect me as captain?

Fields.DialogueText: He would not be wrong if his policies worked. And yet...
He needs to be handled carefully. Or do you want to end up like Nicola?
I... I would not go back on my choice. I have no complaints with you.
Capitano, I acknowledge that you are angry. I don't know what will fix this. I need some time to think.
... Fine. But I'm not done with you.
There's something more to this between you and Zima and it seems to go a long time back. Cavour... what happened at Corfu?
There are Morganas coming. After battle, we will talk.
@BATTLE
Sit, please. This will not be easy.
Do you know the events leading up to the Corfu Incident?
If I ever knew, I've forgotten. Twenty years ago, give or take?
An Italian general, Tellini, was the chair of a commission mediating a border dispute between Greece and Albania.
The Greeks hated him, even openly accused him of favoring Albania.
Tellini and four of his staff were ambushed and murdered near the border. The Greeks tried to blame Albanian bandits... transparently preposterous.
They hadn't been robbed.
Mussolini sent Greece a list of demands that would resolve the situation to Italy's satisfaction.
The Greeks tried to negotiate for a more favorable deal. He took a hard-line stance.
In retaliation, the Regia Marina occupied the island of Corfu. Giulio Cesare and I led the attack.
We bombarded the island's old fortifications, where the Greek garrison should have been.
They weren't?
The Old Fortress was being used to house civilians. Refugees from Asia Minor.
Assuming the worst figures... 20 dead and 32 wounded in the bombardment. None of them soldiers. Most of them children.
My God. And Zima?
Was the counter-admiral in charge of the battle group. Did he know, when he gave the orders? I don't know.
What do you think?
I did not have a say in the operation. I don't thrill at battle the way I imagine Cesare does. I showed up, I did my job. Nonetheless, there is guilt.

Fields.MenuText: You weren't manifested then. There wasn't anything you could have done.
If I let myself be used like that, I would feel guilty too.
I think the important question is, would you have done anything if you could?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe not. Maybe... I don't know.
Could I have stopped anything? It's hard to say.
In hindsight... I would try harder to confirm the targets. Without hindsight... I don't know.
So there. Now you know.
Thank you for telling me. So, Zima?
I'm still not sure. I want to believe Zima's methods will yield results, but you're right about one thing. I owe Nicola an apology at the very least.
Keep thinking. But don't wait too long.
Capitano, there are Morganas in sight! Are you not going to do anything?
Sailors, get ready to–
Sailors, get ready to counterattack! Officers, get your squads ready! Move, now!
@BATTLE
Admiral? A moment?
Yes, what is it?
In Nicola's stead, I have taken over managing the shift schedules. The Capitano has already reviewed these proposed changes and–
Let me see.
You've shortened the work shifts?
The whole point in taking on new recruits was to ease–
Useless. There is so much to get done and not enough time to do it.
Respectfully, Admiral, the crew is not getting enough rest. Performance will suff–
Then give an extra hour of recreation time to the veteran crew. The recruits must still earn their leisure.
Admiral, I–
No more argument. I expect better from you, Cavour.
That could have gone better.

Fields.MenuText: You see, though? He treats the crew like slaves.
You see, though? He won't even let you finish a sentence.
You see, though? If he treats you like that, think of how it is for the rest of us.

Fields.DialogueText: It is... definitely not what I would do.
It is... frustrating.
It is... something to consider.
Sergeant, do you know why I called you in here?
No, Capitano.
You know that Sergeant Hollett is supposed to be responsible for administering punishment details?
Hollett was reassigned, Capitano.
By whom?
Admiral Zima, Capitano.
Did he say why?
I didn't ask, C–errrr... signora. Credere, obbedire, combattere.
... Fine. Dismissed.
That's the fourth officer reassignment this week. All done without my knowledge or input. I'm sure Zima is shuffling his favorites into place.
All Italian, and if they can rattle off Fascist slogans all the better, it seems.
You're growing perceptive, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: So you agree with me?
I'm starting to pick up something from you then.
Of course, I could be wrong about his motives.

Fields.DialogueText: It is obvious, as political machinations go.
A very rudimentary something. But I suppose it is your standing on the line.
No, I am sure you are right.
We will have to continue this discussion later. I think we are about to be called to fight...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Cavour, have you–
Have I what?
Nevermind. You've got that "I'm up to something" look in your eyes... but you're also looking unusually grim.

Fields.MenuText: Please... now is not the time for secrets.
Do I have to order you to spill it?
Knowledge is power, and I need all I can get right now.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Fair. We must act as allies in this.
... No. I will tell you.
You are starting to think like a player. Very well.
... But later. We're about to get some surprise visitors.
@BATTLE
So...
You remember, as a matter of course, that all mail in the fleet is censored?
Yes. For operational security.
I sometimes check the censor's work to ensure it's being done properly.
And this has nothing to do with snooping around for info?
Any information gleaned from them is a useful bonus. Usually there is little that's interesting.
However, I noticed an irregularity. A handful of letters are being ignored by the censor. All claiming to come from sailors that don't exist on the rolls. All to addresses in Rome.
How long has this been going on?
It started after Zima came aboard. I am following up on the names as discreetly as possible, but I believe they are officials in the Fascist Party.
Now, I am certain Zima would not do anything out of line... as far as the Regia Marina is concerned. He is zealously loyal.
I... could see you doing similar. But the INPF is sure to have objections.
Have no illusions, Capitano. Similar games are being played throughout the Fleet. But knowing this puts me in a more difficult position.
I would rat him out without hesitation.
If you would, you must be sure the case is rock solid. I am still confirming my suspicions. Give me time, if you want any chance of success.
C'est ridicule. Quand vont-ils nous laisser nous reposer?
I will pretend I didn't hear that!
Erk! Sorry, Capitaine.
(I'd rather not enforce Zima's rules, but better they be warned by me than caught.)
You'll pretend, will you, Capitano?
(Crap.)

Fields.MenuText: Be reasonable, Zima. They were warned; they stopped.
Be reasonable, Zima. It's no harm if they're talking among themselves.
Be reasonable, Zima. I'm a busy person.

Fields.DialogueText: They will start again the moment they're out of earshot.
And if they're talking about, oh, a mutiny? What then?
More likely a lazy person. No wonder discipline on this ship has slipped.
You know what? Enough. Let's have it out. You don't like me. But there is no call to cut me out of the command structure the way you have.
And what do you think you can do about it?
At worst, you'll have to leave eventually.
You are wrong. I've been considering putting in for a permanent position here.
And you're right, I don't like you. But more importantly, I don't like the flagship of the Regia Marina out of the hands of true loyalists.
The INPF is unlikely to separate a capitano from their Belle. But I can make you irrelevant. And no one is likely to complain, especially given my service record.
No, Admiral.
(Yikes. That's her "quietly furious" look.)
Cavour, this is none of your business.
Everything that happens on these decks is my business. And the way you have been treating my capitano is disgraceful.
If you have a problem with my choice, you have a problem with me. And you cannot simply make me irrelevant.
How dare you challenge me. You think I can't?
I've noticed your little habits... how officials you don't like keep quietly getting reassigned.
I can get you thrown off the BWC. I can find all your contacts and isolate you from them. I can make your duty assignments truly miserable.
Do you think you can succeed?
Do you want to find out?
*ALARM*
What timing. Don't think that I'm done with you.
@BATTLE
Caprara, I found these two speaking Spanish in the mess. Make sure they–
*ALARM*
Damn it, not now! You two, do not even think you are getting away with this.
@BATTLE
Cavour, are you all right? You look like you're in pain.
B-deck, forward. A shell has pierced a seam in the deck armor and it's sitting there unexploded.
Crap! Ok, I'll call ordinance disposal and–
You'll do nothing. I will handle this.
*Some Time Later*
Admiral, I'm begging you, stop trying to rush this! We've got an exhausted crew, a precariously rigged winch and a live shell swinging a meter above the deck!
I don't care what you have to do, I want that thing off my ship!
Then let me do my job instead of yelling at me! Excuse my language, but I don't have time to be nice with the brass!
Your job is to obey orders, you insubordinate little–
It's slipping!
Cazzo! Hit the deck! Hit the de–
*BOOM*
*BOOM*
*ALARM*
Oh God, not now, please not now.
@BATTLE
That came way too quickly after the explosion. I swear the Morganas have a sense for blood in the water.
... Sorry. Let's hear the final damage report.
Three dead from proximity to the explosion. The ordinance tech has internal injuries, but they are survivable. Zima sustained some internal injuries and was concussed.
We are also down one winch and my deck plating is dented, but those are inconsequential.

Fields.MenuText: This was avoidable, you know.
It could have been much worse.
All right. So what do we do now?

Fields.DialogueText: I do.
It should not have happened. I let this go too far.
I do what I should have done much sooner.
Capitano, I am going to face Zima. I would appreciate you there... as an ally.
*Some Time Later*
I don't think you will be talking over me here.
This is what happens when you run men into the ground. This is why I depart from Machiavelli on how to treat soldiers.
Those incompetent–
No. You created this. You cut out every link in the command structure that tried to warn you; you ran the crew so ragged they could barely function.
It starts and ends with you. And I'm going to make sure the world knows it.
I'll have you know, my loyalty to Italy remains unshakable. I let you get this far because I wanted to believe you had good intentions.
But let me make one thing perfectly clear...
I. Am. Not. Your. Ship.
This isn't Corfu anymore. I choose my people. I take responsibility for them. And for God's sake, I confirm my damn targets!
You are finished. When I see you off this ship, it will be in shackles.
Go to hell.
I'll drag you down with me if I have to.
All right, we can do this. There's not many of them, and the crew has been resting. Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Here's the damage reports, Capitano.
Good to see you back in uniform.
Cavour apologized to me a while ago. She was bringing me books so I didn't lose my mind with boredom. But I got to rest at least.
So we've been called to port by the General Staff. Any idea how it will go?
Getting a charge against an officer to stick when there are subordinates to blame it on is an uphill battle.
Your statements, my statements, the crew's statements, all of those will help. But I think a lot hangs on how Cavour manages to sell it.

Fields.MenuText: She hasn't told me much. So I have no idea.
She hasn't told me much. But I trust she knows what she's doing.
She hasn't told me much. I hope we can trust her.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah. She's playing it close to her chest.
She's written popular editorials for the Italian press. So yeah, she probably does.
She might spin it for her own benefit. But I'm confident she's on our side now.
*Some Time Later*
What the hell? The docks are swarming with civilians.
... Oh. She's leaked to the press. The General Staff won't be able to sweep this under the rug so easily.
Admiral Zima, by order of the League of Nations and the INPF, you are under arrest for negligent homicide and negligent hazarding of a vessel under your command.
You are indefinitely relieved of command and will be transported under guard to Zurich, where you can expect to face court martial.
You. I will fight this.
So will I.
I've put in the requests for shore leave. You've gotten the newspapers?
Aye. She's been busy.
The Italian ones are interesting. The reports downplay Zima's involvement, of course. But they've published Cavour's editorial.
Without singling out the Fascists, she made a strong case for the INPF.
She wrote that "Regia Marina ships operating under the Fleet face an enemy beyond mortal understanding... "
"...and to combat this enemy they must have latitude to select the best people, no mater where they come from."
Oh, and look at this headline from the next day. "Italian Leadership Reconfirms Commitment To INPF Operations".
Who knows how sincere they really are, but it's telling they were pressured into a statement.

Fields.MenuText: I doubt either of them are completely sincere.
I doubt the politicals are sincere, but I think Cavour is, in her way.
I'm mostly just glad heads will roll... and that they aren't ours.

Fields.DialogueText: It's hard to tell with Cavour sometimes. But she does seem to care about running things well.
Yeah. She's not one to hold back when she sees things being run badly.
Cheers to that.
Captain? We're being called to port defense. Morganas keep popping out to sortie with harbor traffic.
No rest for the weary...
@BATTLE
Right, shift that plate left a bit more.
Unnf. Damn having to clean up after that bloody admiral...
... As you were.
You think she knows people are mad at her?
She won't let on if she does. That's how it is when the brass have had a fight.
Hm. She probably can't help hearing what's being said behind her back. Almost feel sorry for her... Almost.
*KNOCK*
Cavour?
I just wanted to see how you were doing. If this is a bad time... is that a rosary?
Yes. But you're not unwelcome. Come. Sit.
I've been speaking with the Chaplain Bevila.
It's a bit amusing. The Vatican has been unsure how to reconcile doctrine and the existence of the Belles. They aren't even sure if we have souls.
But between the chaplain and I... we agree there is penance to be done.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think God will forgive you?
Do you think the crew will forgive you?
Do you think you can forgive yourself?

Fields.DialogueText: God will always forgive, if the penitent is sincere. Or so we believe.
Maybe. It will take work and time. I may have to rethink some things.
I... don't know. There is a lot to think... and rethink.
But reconciliation starts with admitting you were wrong.
A leader must maintain a strong public face. But between us, Capitano... I was wrong. I am sorry.
I accept your apology. But I think it will take a while for me to process this myself.
I understand.
@BATTLE
We are ready for departure with the next tide. But there is a courier on the dock saying they have a delivery?
Ah, that's for me. Send word down to accept it.
*Some Time Later*
Pots, soil, and... sunflower seeds?
And a bouquet, for some cheer in the meantime. I think we can mount the pots on the navigation bridge where there's plenty of windows.
Consider it a peace offering.
So you're willing to forgive me?

Fields.MenuText: I think it will still take time, but I'm willing to work on it.
I'm not sure, knowing what you believe. But I would rather have you as an ally than not.
I do forgive you. I value you as an ally... and a friend.

Fields.DialogueText: That is fair. I think that's true for both of us.
Your regard is something I may have to pay more attention to in the future.
I... thank you, Capitano. I wasn't actually expecting that.
A wise leader choses their allies carefully. I am glad to have you as one.
Capitano, our departure's been moved up. Port defense needs reinforcement. The Morganas aren't interested in giving us a break.
Onward to the next campaign then. Right, Capitano?
